newsitem.title: ITALY: PRESS DIGEST - Italy - Friday, Feb 7.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Italy - Friday, Feb 7.

text.p: Following are some of the top headlines in leading Italian newspapers.

* Massimo D'Alema, leader of Italy's Democratic Party of the Left, called a meeting he had with German Chancellor Helmut Kohl "positive and reassuring" on the subject of economic and monetary union. Prime Minister Romano Prodi is scheduled to meet Kohl today (all).
* In an interview Herbert Hax, economic advisor to Chancellor Kohl, says Italy has a 10 to 20 percent probability of joining EMU in the first wave (La Stampa).

* Hard-left Refoundation Communist party leader Fausto Bertinotti reaffirmed the state should maintain a 51 percent stake after the sell-off of telecom holding Stet, while electricity utility group Enel should remain in public hands. Bertinotti also fiercely criticised the relaxing climate between opposition and government, after centre-right bloc leader Silvio Berlusconi said he would accept to bring forward the 1998 budget if it included pensions cuts. Bertinotti threatened to withdraw his party support to the ruling coalition unless it rejects Berlusconi's proposals (all).
*The government is expected to meet railway trade unions which called a general strike to protest against a planned reform of state railway company Ferrovie dello Stato (all).
* Industrial holding IRI approved the procedure for selecting the global coordinator to oversee the sell-off of its motorway operator unit Autostrade (all).

* Italian investment funds had a net inflow of 18.327 trillion lire in January, compared with a net inflow of 9.177 trillion lire in December. The net inflow into Italian equity funds was 1.795 trillion lire from 368 billion lire in December.
* Researcher group Centro Studi Promotor expects Italian car sales to rise to 255,000, up 33 percent over January 1996, helped by the government's car buying scheme (all).

* France Telecom will reportedly very soon join Olivetti's fixed-line telecoms joint venture Infostrada. The French group would pay more than 100 billion lire to buy a 49 per cent stake in the company, while the remaining 51 percent would go to Infoinvestment, a joint-venture between Bell Atlantic and Olivetti Telemedia. An agreement should be announced by the end of the week (La Repubblica).
** Reuters has not verified these stories and cannot vouch for their accuracy.
